awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF-P: Rapid Organizational Assimilation in On-demand Work through Social Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The Internet and related technologies have transformed the way of work, by allowing people to work remotely, and increasingly, on short-term projects or gigs. Online platforms make it easier for workers to find short-term work and for employers to hire freelancers for their short-term needs. Such short-term work arrangements offer workers the independence and flexibility they desire, while at the same time allowing companies to momentarily tap into external knowledge and experiences their workforce lacks. However, short-term workers today exist on the fringes of their temporary workplaces and find it challenging to build social connections within the organizations that hire them, affecting both their well-being and productivity negatively. Workers from minority or marginalized groups are particularly impacted negatively. This project will develop a research program that accelerates assimilation into future work settings through a unique partnership with two industry collaborators, who operate at very different scales and rely on freelancers to varying degrees: one partner is a small business with fewer than a hundred permanent employees, the other partner is a large, multinational information-technology and research company that operates in many countries. In coordination with these partners, the researchers will organize a series of workshops to create a focused research agenda that is beneficial for workers and organizations broadly. Based on this agenda, the project team will include diverse stakeholders, such as industry representatives, workers, and researchers, who can then make progress on this research agenda. This planned research will also train graduate students across multiple disciplines, including computer science, social sciences, and organizational science. Given the central emphasis on inclusion and access, the project will place particular emphasis on recruiting women, students of color, and first-generation students to contribute to this research. 

This project brings together several disciplines, including learning science, computer science, and social psychology. The intellectual contribution of this proposal is to establish the requirements and key technological affordances of a work environment for rapid assimilation through social learning. This is done by focusing on the design of socialization tools for remote gig workers. The research is highly integrative and converges expertise from social/behavioral sciences and computer/learning science. The team is structured to achieve multiple convergent goals: To address the need for rapid assimilation of on-demand workers into organizations, this research will uncover the social and technical needs for digital and physical environments that accelerate newcomer situated learning and assimilation. Second, it will build a diverse and cross-disciplinary team to build such environments in planned future research. Finally, this project will positively impact a highly skilled, and economically significant workforce of information workers at large, and the project's research agenda is likely to particularly help female and underrepresented workers be more included in the workforce. This agenda will outline key research questions, quantitative and qualitative study methodologies, and evaluation metrics for designing environments (both digital and physical) that enhance work practices in assimilation and socialization, with an emphasis on access, inclusion, and equity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project seeks to create computer-supported methods to accelerate assimilation of members in the workplace. It departs from prior work in that it views work as what happens happens in context – work comprises practices that are informed by situated knowledge, rather than generalized, context-free best practices. Furthermore, it builds on the idea that how we think is not just "influenced by" the tools we use and environments we inhabit, but that these tools and environments  "implement" the practices. In this way, we see our workplace as a distributed "hardware", of which the brain is but one component alongside other materials such as other people, technological support, and the structure of one's environment.

Initially, we studied organizations that are made up of many short-term information workers, such as platform workers (using platforms like Upwork), and those that employ remote workers generally. This focus was informed by our hypothesis that these organizations need to create work environments that allow short-term members of the organization to rapidly assimilate into the organization, and to learn new skills socially. We also  thought that these kinds of organizations would become increasingly widespread, with increasing remote work. 

Our initial work resulted in reflective online environments that helped teams think about how they work together, and to give each other roles that reflected their work patterns. We found that one such environment (Retrospector) did improve team outcomes (N=75). Surprisingly, we also found that team members themselves could not notice the improvement, and were just as satisfied with their team outcomes. This leads us to think that either the improvements are small, or that at least some suboptimal team practices are hard for members to notice themselves. 

In another prototype environment (Nooks), we found techniques to match participants with other members who shared their interests in the workplace (such as golf, or board games.) We found that because members could share their interests anonymously, and only reveal their identity after finding others similarly interested, they were more likely to share their interests and meet new people in the organization.

Over the course of the project, we realized that while indeed remote work was increasing, the larger change was the rapid development of new AI models, particularly large language models (LLMs.) We thus focused our efforts both on understanding how AI affects how workers communicate with each other and built environments that used AI to help them communicate more effectively. 

Existing work shows that if a message is known to be written with AI, the recipient judges the sender as less warm, i.e. less trustworthy and less kind, than in absence of such knowledge. However, in our empirical work, we show this is not always true. In fact, we found that such judgments were only true for certain kinds of communication. Prior work examined categories of communication that normatively evidence warmth (ex. condolences, ice-breakers), where knowledge about AI use reduces perceived warmth of the sender. However, these are not the only kinds of messages in organization, so our investigation includes communication that normatively evidences a lack of warmth: brags and blames. Our experiment (N=280) demonstrates that indication of AI-assistance leads to lower warmth judgments when thanking and apologizing, but not when bragging and blaming. We argue (and our study shows) the effect of AI use is better understood as suppressing positive character evaluations rather than evoking distaste.

Based on these and other findings, we introduced a new genre of LLM based conversational assistants for “social preparation”. Social preparation is the work of preparing for high-stakes social interactions. Many AI systems focus solely on providing solutions or explaining outcomes. However, for tasks like social preparation, correctness of the solutions is dependent on who the social actors are (i.e. the same solution isn’t always right.) To help peripheral participants, we introduce a new genre of assistants that help users improve decision-making in social situations. 

We call our approach a “thinking assistant” as it combines asking reflection questions based on expert knowledge. Through our lab study (N=80), these Large Language Model (LLM) based assistants were better able to guide users to make important decisions, compared with conversational agents that only asked questions, provided advice, or neither.  

Together, this research points to a future where AI tools can both be responsibly used in the workplace for more successful assimilation of new workers, and new environments can help workers reflect on their experiences and be more effective in the workplace.
